title: Principles

articles.content:
A principle is “a fundamental, primary, or general truth, on which other truths
depend.” Thus a principle is an abstraction which subsumes a great number of
concretes. It is only by means of principles that one can set one’s long-range
goals and evaluate the concrete alternatives of any given moment. It is only
principles that enable a man to plan his future and to achieve it.
articles.attribution:
“The Anatomy of Compromise,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 144

articles.content:
Concrete problems cannot even be grasped, let alone judged or solved, without
reference to abstract principles.
articles.attribution:
“Credibility and Polarization,”
The Ayn Rand Letter, I, 1, 3

articles.content:
You have no choice about the necessity to integrate your observations, your
experiences, your knowledge into abstract ideas, i.e., into principles. Your
only choice is whether these principles are true or false, whether they
represent your conscious, rational convictions—or a grab-bag of notions
snatched at random, whose sources, validity, context and consequences you do
not know, notions which, more often than not, you would drop like a hot potato
if you knew. . . .
articles.attribution:
“Philosophy: Who Needs It,”
Philosophy: Who Needs It, 5

articles.content:
Consider a few rules about the working of principles in practice and about the
relationship of principles to goals . . . .
articles.attribution:
“The Anatomy of Compromise,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 145

articles.content:
When men abandon principles (i.e., their conceptual faculty), two of the major
results are: individually, the inability to project the future; socially, the
impossibility of communication.
articles.attribution:
“Credibility and Polarization,”
The Ayn Rand Letter, I, 1, 3

articles.content:
Only fundamental principles, rationally validated, clearly understood and
voluntarily accepted, can create a desirable kind of unity among men.
articles.attribution:
“Credibility and Polarization,”
The Ayn Rand Letter, I, 1, 4
